div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: AUFGEBOT.
div.p: Es wird hiermit bekannt gemacht, dass der preussische Staatsangehörige Friedrich August Jalins Jepp, seines Standes Zollinspektor bei der egyptiscben Zollverwaltung, geboren in Warlubien, 51 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Alexandrien, Sohn des in Graudenz im Jahre 1889 verstorbenen Spediteurs Friedrich Jepp, ond dessen im Jahre 1897 in Grandenz verstorbenen Ehefrau Angustine geborene Meister
und

die preussische Staatsangehörige Josephine Renck, geboren in Hagen, 37 Jahre alt, wohnbaft in Berlin, Tochter des im Jahre 1890 in Berlin verstorbenen Ingenieurs Wilhelm Renck und dessen in Berlin wohnbaften Ehefrau Julie, geborene Heinsel, beabsichtigen sich mit einander zu verebelichen und diese Ehe in Gemässheit des Reichsgesetzes vom 4. Mai 1870 vor dem unterzeichneten Beamten ab zuschliessen Alexandrien, den 14. November 1907.
gez. WUNDERLICH.

div.head: OUR "REALPOLITIK."
div.p: Commenting on the Kaiser's visit to Engni land the "Tribune" says :

Were it only for its personal interest the visit is an event which must attract public attention in a very exceptional measure, and must excite a new volume of speculation as to the parts which the German and British Sovereigns have played, and will still play, in the life of their communities and the world at largo. They are clearly marked and, in some ways, highly contrasted individualities, and I yet the popularity of each among his own people rests largely in the fact that they exhibit some of the most characteristic traits of the two nations. King Edward, with his good nature and common sense, his business like and sportsmanly spirit; his regard for onnstitutional limits and the progressive tendency of his time, and even in his discovery, at the moment when the British monareby appeared to have entered into a passive and decorative phase, of new possibilities in in ternational diplomacy, is one of the most typical of Englishmen. The Kaiser has some more brilliant gifts, and standing amidst & community the agrarian and industrial extremes of which are even further removed than they are with us, it is not surprising that he should sometimes appear as an almost medieval figure, and at other times as aggressively modern in ambition and sentiment. He never speaks of acts or moves about under the public eye, however, without illustrating the ludicrous falsity of that picture which certain British Teutophobes have lately placed before us, in which Germany is represented as the Moloch of the modern world, a unavimous and compact body, ma terialistic to the core, and harbouring ideals only of universal conquest. In the versatile personality of the Emperor are, gathered up many of the exceedingly diverse notes of local character very incompletely unified in the Ger man Empire. This is no man of Blood and Iron, of the Bismarekian cast; and if there is much in him of Prussian conservatism, and of that faith in force which is the evil fruit of the war of Unity, there is also much of unquestionably sincere moral sentiment and idealism. There is no question--and this matter of the importance of which recent events remind usof the integrity of his personal and family life; and there is equally no question of his devotion to the welfare of his people as he conceives it The two peoples have lost much in the recent past by something like an estrangement of the two Courts. If the meeting of the King and Kaiser meant nothing more than an end to this period of coldness, it would mean much.

Of course, it means a great deal more how much will depend upon the Kaiser's appreciation of his own powers and the possibilities of the future, bat a great deal in any case. It is to be hoped that it may complete that movement of friendship which, commenced simultaneously in Germany and England two years ago by the Anglo-German Conciliation Committee, and carried forward by the visits of British editors to Germany and German editors to this country, received official sanction in the messages of leading states men on either side, and in the meeting of the two Sovereigns at Wilhelmshohe on Aug. 14th last. This is in itself a great result for the friends of international peace to have won in so short a time. The suppressed feud between the two Empires has produced absolutely no good result; it has, on the other hand, added enormously to the burdens which each people has to bear, and has kept alive a spirit of distrust and alarm which has injured them both. Henceforward it should be an axiom on both sides that, whatever small cliques of mischiefmakers may say, the responsiblestatesmen of both countries intend not only to maintain, but to develop, the friendly understanding that now happily obtains. We may go further, and express the hope that this visit implies, on the part of the Kaiser and his Government, & recognition of that part of British foreign policy which, often mistepresented in an aggressive sense at home, has still more often been misunderstood as minatory in Germany. It has been so long the custom to regard, and it still suits the purposes of so many renetionaries to represent, a peace policy as alternately sentimental and mischief-making that these misunderstandings do not greatly surprise es. The fiery birth of the German Empire is still dominant me mory. But ever.ts move fast nowadays; and the German no more than any other progres sive people can afford to lag behind in the development which is as ebaracteristic and important as the application of a new motive power in manufacture, or the periodical revision of scientifie text-books. There is a "realpolitik" of peace, as well as of war, of Democracy as well as of Empire. The idea of a League of Peace, which the Prime Minister has explainod, and of which King Edward has been the most efficient diplomatie agent, is neither the sentimental vision which English Torice have sometimes represented it to be, nor the antiGerman conspiracy which Herr Bassermami and his fellow-Bismarekans imagine. It is a perfectly honest business programme. It is a Datural statement of British interests, the interests of a country largely dependent on overses trade, and therefore desirous of nothing so much as permanent peace and a cheaper security than is given by ever-increasing armaments. But these interests are also the interests of every modern industrial State. We have not forced France and Spain, Russia and Japan, into the compacts we have made with them. Those compacts exist and can continue only by virtue of mutual material advantage. Is Germany, then, some prodigious exception in the field of economic law 1 Can she afford to continue to go about in her workshops and laboratories clad in tendal armour, while competing States, not lacking in power and determination, are bargaining together for the mutual insurance of their capital and labour ! We do not believe it. And it is because the Kaiser has giyen abundant proof of mental vigour and imagination, that we cannot soppose him wishful to stand aside when change so immense and beneficent is in question.

div.p: There is absolutely no truth in the statement which has been made that the budget of 1908 will provide for the creation of two new English Inspectors for the provinces.

div.head: Slavery in Egypt.
div.p: During the month of October this year there were five Sudanese placed on the manumission list, one man of the Siout province in Upper Egypt, two women and one man in Cairo, a one woman at Alexandria.

div.head: Plague in Egypt.
div.p: There have been five cases of plague and two deaths reported during the last twent four hours, this brings the number of cases present under treatment to fourteen, which a rather large increase upon the numbe treated for the past few weeks. There ha been 1,157 cases under treatment and 8 desths from January the 1st to November 17 this year.

div.head: Workmen Strike at Constantinople.
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of th "Times" in a message dated the 9th insta states: Probably for the first time in the hi tory of Constantinople, 300 workmen went o strike at Stamboul on Thursday, demandin an increase of wages in order to enable them meet the huge increase in the cost of liviu due to the bad barvest and the scarcity of fue "The dispute will probably be arranged withou difficulty, but the incident, which was imm diately reported to the palace, is interestin in more ways than one.

div.head:
EGYPT AND THE SUDAN.
THE NEW ROUTE
div.p: FROM LONDON TO SUDAN IN 8 DAYS
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).

Port Sudán, Saturday, November 9. A new era in the history of the communice tion of the Sudan with the outside world began this evening when the Khedivial Mail Com pany's SS. "Prince Abbas" arrived in th harbour of Port Sudan with the mails, whicl had left Charing Cross Station on the previou Friday evening for Brindisi, thus bringing the Sudan within eight days of London, whereby Khartoum will be brought twenty four hour nearer to Egypt and England than has hithert been possible by the quickest express service by way of the Nile. Great interest has been manifested by the Sudan Government and the Egyptian Postal Administration in this in augural trip and the Egyptian Railway Administration will attach a special through carriage for Suez Docks by the 11 o'clock train every Wednesday from Cairo, thus enabling passengers for the Sndan to escape the necessity of changing carriages at Ismailis. On the present occasion the Railway Administra tion selected one of their oldest and dirties first and second class composite carriages for the journey. In future it is to be hoped that the Administration will be more careful in the choice of through carriages. One is quite insufficient and as the Sudan Government officials travel with their servants, one third class counpartment for servants should be included "The train connecta at Ismailia with the P. & 0. Brindisi Mail from Port Said and is due at Suez Docks at 5 p m. As this was the first foreign mail train in connection with a past ateamer service, which has ever drawn up at Buez since the abandonment of the old overand route to the East, some delay was to be expected and it occurred. The officials of the Quarantine Service were totally inadequate and although there was a large number of first, econd, and third class passengers, besides un abundance of luggage and the mails, only one gangway gave admission to the ship, because of the paucity of Quarantine officials. Purther delay, which it will be easy to obviate n the future, took place because every pasenger had to display his passport to the official of the Passport Office before setting his bót on the gangway. The rule that every merson entering the Badan should have a nassport from the Sudan Government is . wise provision, but there is no rhyme nor messon in delaying the departure of an express mail steamer in order that high and well known

fficials in the service of the Sudan Government should be obliged to show their passports. n future this source of delay must be obviated y a single official boarding the train at Rue Colmar Station and examining all the passports refore the train reaches Suez Dock. One of the most important points for travellers, by this pute is to see that their loggage is registered trongh at Cairo to Suez Docks and not to Suez
otherwise it is very possible that all their aggage will be left behind at the Rue Colmar tation.

The train draws up close alongside the beamer and the position in this respect could tot be more convenient. The train arrived unctually at 4.30 pm, and the boat was scheuled to leave half-an-hour afterwards' As it as, owing to this quite needless delay, it did ot get away until an hour afterwards. The ecessity of leaving punctually to time is espeally important in this service, for although oth the mail steamers, "Prince Abbas" (Capin Williams) and "Al Kahira" (Captain yall) can steam at the rate of sixteen knots
hour, the Red Sea is the only sea in the orld where a vessel can go quicker against
e north wind than with it. Even on the premt voyage in November the heat was so great

d the wind being abaft obliged the slowing wn of the steamer owing to the difficulties mich the stokers met with in keeping her ing at full speed, the steamer not being fitted th forced draughts. The two steamers for this w service are very comfortable and were wellown to travellers between Alexandris and onstantinople before they were replaced by e 9.8. "Osmanieh" anul the 8.s. "Ismailia." ne only suggestion we have to make is that e first class cabins be fitted with electric fans d forved dranghts put in. There is plenty room everywhere, the promenade deck is ople, and the vessels are in every re-peet alt st improvement on the old steamers, which ve been hitherto the only way of reaching

Red Sea ports of the Sudan from Egypt. ne "Prince Abbas" was due to arrive at Port dan at 6 p.m. on Friday, making torty nine urs from Suez, but for the reasons above entioned she did not enter the new harbour

the Sadan until over nine hours later, nder special arrangement with the Sudan vernment Railways a train with sleeping d dining cars was in readiness to meet the 1 amer and the mails and passengers were f edily sboard for Khartoum, where they
due at 8 p mi on Saturday The mail steamer goes on to Suakim, return
to Port Sudan on Tuesday next and ving on Thursday at 10 a.m. for Suez. om Khartoum a train with sleeping and ning cats leaves in connection with the li meward mail steamer every Tuesday at
5 pm. arriving at Port Sudan on Wednes ys at 8 pm. Passengers may remain infi

sleeping ears and embark on Thursday mning. On their, arrival at Suez through riages are attached to the 5.40 p m. train Cairo on the following Saturday. The new route must compete with the old y by the Nile especially in the case of officials

Khartoum and the South, for twenty four mrs is a considerable saving in the journey to and from Cairo. No doubt tourists will als patrooise the new route • pleasant alterna tive to returning northwards again by the Nile For all those who wish to get back to England As soon as possible from Khartoum "this i the only way owing to the connection with th Port Said and Brindisi route, which thus bring Khartoum within nine days of London. The Sudan Government and the Khedivial Mai Line are to be congratulated on their enterpris in having organised this new service, which it is to be hoped will be largely patronised by officials and men of business, who are desirous of reaching the Budin in the shortest most comfortable manner possible.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: THE RETURN TO CAIRO.

The departure of the Khedive this morning to the Capital attracted a large crowd of people who lined the streets, and at the station every official of high standing and many of the civil motabilities of Alexandris were present to bid this Highness good bye. His Highness journey to Cairo was interrupted by several stops, at bach of which he graciously received those who were present to welcome bira, and on his arrival at Cairo he was met by the official world of the Capital. Both on departure From Alexandria and arrival at Cairo salutes of 21 guns were fired and full honours rendered.

The return of His Highness to Cairo may well be considered to mark the official opening of the winter season and its atteteatt fessivities, which, it is expected, will be on a more extended and brittiant scate than on any previous occasion. The cordial reception, which was given to his Highness this morning.
hows that the popolarity of this enlightened Hovereign is ever on the upward grade and

robably not a few amongst those, who greeted nim, were imbued with a feeling of wympathy not alone for their Monarch but for that father, who has been anxiously watching by the bedside f his two little ones so recently struck down y typhoid fever, but now happily on the Dad to recovery. The dangerous malady, from which the Heir Apparent and his sister have now escaped, must have intensified the sentiments of loyalty in which every Egyptian relcomes back the Khedive to his capital. "nder these trying circumstances it was remarkble to see now well His Highness was looking md with what cordiality he received his meople's greetings.

We cannot refrain from congratulating His lighness on the altered relations, which axist etween the Palace and the Agency since Şir Idon Gorst has assumed the post vacated by ord Cromer. When the Khedive last came to kiro for the winter the state of affairs was ery different from what it is at present and all etions of the population beartily rejoice in e improvement that has taken place, for it is Illy recognised that these new conditions are e best guarantee for the effective working of e administration and the stability of the untry,

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK LTD.
div.p: We published on Friday last the balance Det and profit and loss account of the Angloyptian bank to the 31st of August 1907, t have been compelled to refrain from mmenting upon the same owing to a superandance of matter. We are now able, however, offer our congratulations to the management,
also to the shareholders, on this report, ich is highly interesting to us and, we are 1 re, will interest the majority of our readers. We

especially interested in that it thoroughly nfirms the opinion that we have so often 1 pressed in the "Egyptian Gazette," viz. at, whatever may have been the loss to the f meral public in Egypt by reason of the heavy rinkage in values of stocks and shares during

year, the large banks here have known how protect themselves and that the losses they we sustained during the period of the crisis ve been borne by those extra reserve funds cealed as liabilities to "other accounts."
comparison of the balance sheet for thelb ancial years 1901 and 1907 reveals tho 16 raordinary growth of the business of the glo-Egyptian Bank. At the earlier period
capital paid up amounted to £100,000 the reserve fund to £250,000. Six years er the paid up capital stands at £500,000
the reserve at £590,000, the increase of 10,000 in the latter item in six years to
ing been made by an addition of £100,000 miom on further issue of capital and in less m£240,000 by transfer from profit and

Forther transfers for various pension ds have been provided from profit and loss, ! we have no doubt that a considerable pont has been secreted in order to further engthen the bank's position so as to make

provision for all futare debts. "he proportion of cash beld by the banki inst liabilities to shareholders and clients be fighly satisfactory and, including liabilities be bills rediscounted, amounts to 19% This, we have always contended is sound, slike shareholders and creditors of the bank the creditors there is the forthier security mcalled capital. Wa recently criticised the on of continental banks with fully paid ital which trade on about one third of the portion of cash reserved by British banks,
we are pleased to note that the Anglo tre ptian bank maintains the best traditions of ish banking.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL AND CO. LIMITED
div.p: THE THREE STANDARDS."

It was, if we are not mistaken, Lot Milner, who in his brilliant essay entitle "England in Egypt" described this couutry the land of opera bouffe. In that descriptio be oxtainly did not err. Innumerable insta 008 might be cited in proof thereof and on of the latest occurred at the general meetin of Mustapha Pasha Kamel and Compan Limited, which was held a few days ago

It should be premised that the compan was formed a year ago in order to create fund for the establishment of two new dail bewspapers, one in French, the ottier i English, viz "L'Eténard Bgyptien" and th Bgyptian Standard."
The capital of the company was LE 20,00 Hivided futo LE. 100'shares and the articles

sociation provided that the Director wast old his post for life, that he was to have th management of these newspapers, both com mercially and politically, was to be solely entrust ad to bite. Such a proposition in any countri out Egypt would have stood but litt bance of bellig flosted: Egypt, however us predicted by Lord Milner, fortis an'excep ion. It is suffictent here to be endowed wit mergy, hardihood and a ready flow of language o gain adherents for almost any cause, how ver still the likelihood of its realisation The LB. 20,000 therefore was readily sub cribed and the two papers sprang into being of their usefulness the publie must be the best mdge. One thing we may assert, however, with at laying ourselves open to the charge of artiality and that is that they reflect to the milest extent the personal antipathias of

ustapha Pashs Kamel, and that the latter hiefly consist of a wholesale and indiscriminate enunciation of England and all her works in ne Valley of the Nile. No day is allowed to ass without some outrageous act of British rutality being chronicled therein. At this
eeting, which we learn from the "Egyptian standard" was attended by the great majority
shareholders, "Our Director explained the osition of the two newspapers and the happy sulta obtained. After a few months' existence, The Egyptian Standard" and the "Etendard

yptien assumed not only in the local ress but in the world's press the important le destined for them by the thought of their undeis. "They have revealed to farope and to mgland in particular the true situation of gypt and the sentiments of the Egyptian nople. Through their means England and arope hitherto deceived by the lies of the mperialist Press are no longer able to ignore e claims of the great people which throughout e entire Nile Valley demands loudly its perty and independende. Their daily action

longer allows indifference to exist. The two wspapers were founded with a restricted pital by a small number of patriots They d judged it proper that no appeal shonld made to the great pablie until the timetss and utility of this work were demonated. This turn has now come. ) "Our Director proposes accordingly to the uneral Assembly to vote the doubling of the pital which is thus brought tp to 240,000. he old shares were each for £100. The new ares will be each £6. Bach old share will ordingly represent 20 new shares. The neral Assembly voted the proposal." A vote of thanks was subsequently offered by • Assembly to Mistapha Pasha Kamel, those eloquence and ceaseless activity," the
poser said, "were expended in order to make ypt and Europe heat the demands of the yptian People and whose ardent patriotism
contribated so much to the growing success our great cause." We can fancy that this will not be partienlar. agreeable reading to those of the Egyptians,
still look såvely forward to the regeneron upon prudent lines of their native country.

we could in any way gange their senti. mts we shonld imagine thelt rising m the perusal of the account of such a eting with a feeling of utter dismay. Men h a practical turn of mind must be aware t this fresh appeal to the Egyptian public

funds is to say the least of it, wholly ating in a businesslike character, for it at never be forgotten that the Company, mgh highly sensoned by the Director with riotism, is first and foremost a commer. undertaking and that when meetings of

character are held it is the invariable otice to circulate with the notice coning the meeting, a report of the year's beedings and a balance sheet showing profit and loss on the enterprise. In the ent case, however, the shareholders seem ave been content that vague, generalities cherp appeals to sentiment should be ac ed as a sufficient substitute. It should be nd, however, that, perhaps with a keen per ion of the present financial depression, the reholders were not asked to dip their handa
their own pockets, but the shares are now red for public subscription and that
LE 100 shares are split up into aty parts of LR 5 each. We shall be rested to see with what avidity they may aken up by the public. One of the clever

thrown out in order to induce them to chase was that their names shall be kept at. If really Kamel's party is as he re ents, a "national movement" why should ole be frightened that their names should sar! We should have expected just Ppposite. What surprises us most is that the ptian Law relating to limited liability panies should not be more stringent and

in the annual publication of reports and mee sheets. If such were the case, we have Holesome fear that it would be found that the original capital of LE. 20,000 had alread been expended, "in revealing to Europe au to Eligtand in particular the lies of the To perialist Press and the claims of this grea people, which throughout the entire Ni Valley demands loudly its liberty and in dependence."

It is rare in our experience that we has read . speech of a chairman of a compan delivered at a general meeting of sharebo ders, which could vie with that of Kami for self-assurance and boundless audacity But really on the whole sach proceedin as we have just recorded is not a little die couraging. What hope can there be for th mational aspirations of Bgyptians when man, professing such subversive principle should have gained over them such a wide spread ascendeney 1

div.head:
FOOTBALL
ST. ANDREW F.C. . INNISKILLING
div.p: FUSILIERS.

The Saint Andrew team again journeyed to Tastapha on Saturday last where they opposed he Inniskillings. The conditions were not of me best, a high wind upsetting to some extent ne judgment of the players. Saints won the
se and elected to play against the wind and me bill, and the first half was confined chiefly

the Saints end. Good shooting on the part the home men was at a discount, but Curtis ad some hot shots to handle. Keill and Parry t up a strong defence and kept the oppositig rwards from getting too close in on Curtis's harge. Saints had two or three runs upon the
mester's ebarge, and from one of thebe Jones ad tard lines in not scoring. Strong kicking

the visiting backs and halved confined the ay for a time to midfield but close on time e Fusiliers almost scored through their inside ght who was in a distinctly off side position, at Curtis saved grandly. The referee displayed tle knowledge of the game, and on several
asions the Pusiliers got the ball when off Re, but the infringement was allowed to pass. ortunately, no scoring took place. The teams Ossed over still level.

The Saints with everything, now in their wour, looked like winning, but this half was t long in progress when it was noticed that ere was a distinct falling off in the forward e. Smith Tacked judgment in his placing, tting the ball to the feet of the opposing halves
backs instead of to his own forwards, Orrison and Jones indulged in "some good ng play, but could seldom get the ball back im centre. Sainta halves were having 3
to do, and Cassels particularly played well. About 15 minutes of this half had gone with
teams still level, when Keill missed hending ball through a flukey wind, and this gave

Fusilier's centre his opportunity, Curtis pped his shot, but before he could dear, the I was rushed through. It was a lucky gorl, I was harddly deserved on play. Saints tried a to equalise and althongh a couple of mers came their way they could not get nough and time was called with the score
iskillings 1 Saints 0. l'he home forwards were superior to the nts, but nevertheless they were well held is

d by the Saints delenee, which was superior che homesters'. Had the game ended in a Alless draw it would have been a hetter ination of the ran of the play, but fortune oured the home men and they won.

Brkoweit, the Bimla of the Sudan, is nearly 4,000 feet above sea level and hither the jaded AngloBudanese officials betake themselves to enjoy he fresh air and lovely mountain scenery - There is running water on this favoured, spot nd the verdure is phenomenal in such an rid country. div.head: CAIRO STREET NUISANCES.
div.p: To The Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir, I read with the greatest interest e article appearing in van BAND Wafab. ader heading "Dangers in Caito," and fully Tee with your Cairo borrespondent ho ho all describes the deplorable condition of out aportant thorongblares sete another nnisce to which I now wish to alade, calling for
itinediste attention of the responsible and mpetent authorities.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Comme nous le faisions entrevoir dans notre chronique financière de samedi, la tendance a été ce matin d'une lourdeur caractéristique. Et ce n'était pas en de des marchés indeeis on les Avis sont partagés, non, tout le monde était d'accord pour reconnaitre que les offres abon. dent et que les acheteurs sont rares. En un mot, nombre de détenteurs actuels sont si désireux de 'alléger de tout ou partie de leur stook qu'ils consentiraient volontiers des réductions de prix, mais les demandes ayant fait défaut, la baisse n'a pas été trop prononcée. On attribue la mauvaise humeur de la place à la hausse du taux privé à 7%. a l'augmentation du taux d'intérêt local et à l'éloignement croissant que témoignent l'épargne et le capital pour des valeurs qui ne lui ont donné depois quelque temps que des déceptions.
En régume, la matinde a été nulle comme affaires et la cote a subi une dépression presque générale sur les valeurs abordées. Au surplus,
tendance est franchement mauvaise. Contrai: rement aux jours précédents, la spéculation n'a pas manipulé de titres de façon particulière, et cela faute d'acheteurs.

Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, l'Agricole flé. chit de 7 7/8 à 7 25/32, la National Bank de 20 5/16 à 19 3/4, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie de 270 à 265, la Daira de 12 1/2 à 12 3/8, la Béhéra de 21 1/4 & 20 1/2 et robligation Crédit Foncier de 289 à 288 l'ancienne et de 254 à 253 la nouvelle.
Bo baisse également la Land Bank de 7 à 6 15/16, l'Urbaine de 3 1/16 à 3, l'Union Poncière de 4 9/16 à 4 1/2, le Crédit FrancoEgyptien de 4 1/16 à 4 et la Banque d'Orient de 112 111 1/2.

Dans la catégorie des petites valeurs la Cassa di Sconto rétrograde de 45 1 2 à 43, la Delta Land de 1 3/8 à 1 1/4, les Sucreries de 33 X 32 fr., l'ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/6 120, les Estates de 7/16 à:13, 32, le Comptoir de 2 17/32 à 2 3/8 l'action et de 1 1/2 à 17 16 la part de fondateur, l'Aboukir de 25/3 à 25 la Lavant de 17/32 I 1/2, l'United de 1/4 & 7/82 l'action et de 1 à 3/4 la fondateur, l'aetion Zariffa de 3 à 2 7/8.
Il n'y a en reprise que les Dividendes Bière du Caire de 25 26 franes et la Banque d'Athènes de 107 1/2 & 108. Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement & signaler.

Nous voudrions bien pouvoir donner l'espoir d'une reprise prochaine ; malheureusement les circonstances actuelles sont défavorables. De plus, nous allons rentrer dans la saison des inventaires, qui n'est généralement pas favo rable au marché des valeurs. Cependant, les porteurs de bonnes valeurs locales ne doivent pas perdre leur sang froid. La cote est maintenant ou de moins est proche d'un niveau avantageux de capitalisation. Ce niveau atteint, une réaction est inévitable.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de banes en bois, avec pieds en fer courbé.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LEg. 20 (vingt).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau des Paros et Plantations où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur, l'Administrateor de la Municipalité avant le 26 Novembre 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en ontre la mention : "Soumission pour "Fourniture de bancs en bois."
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque prévu au cahier des charges devra être versé su Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 26 novembre de 9h. & midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 14 Novembre 1907.
L'Administrateur 31315-3-2 (Signé) W.P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS Le publie est informé que la Municipalité procèders à la vente aux enchères publiques au Palais Municipal (Bureau des Recettes), le Sataedi 16 courant à 11 heures a.m, de
2 chevaux
1 victoria non-numérotée. Cette vente aura lieu en exécution d'une saisie pratiquée à l'encontre du propriétaire.
Le prix adjugé sera payé immédiatement en plas da 2% pour droits de criée, dès la réception des objets sus-dits, réception qui doit avoir lieu le jour même de l'achat.
L'Administrateur (Signe:) W.P. CHATAWAY. 31300-3-2 Alexandrie, le 12 Novembre 1907.

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
